title: 108_hr914
content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" is introduced to exclude space-related income from gross income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act aims to provide tax benefits for space-related activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income, defining it as income derived from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalty amounts related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes certain services and wages from taxation, including telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and transportation services to or from outer space. Additionally, it allows for proportional allocation of income between space-based and earth-based activities for products produced partly in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal taxes if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons. Benefits phase out after 2012, reducing the exclusion amount by x/10th's each year. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products made in outer space from federal taxes if launched from or made at a US-owned facility. The section also includes provisions for recapture if the issuer of the qualified stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years. The act does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. Amendments are made to the general business credit section to include the space company investment credit. No carryback of the space company investment credit is allowed before January 1, 2004. The company investment credit under section 45G can be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2004. Amendments are made to include the space company investment credit in the general business credit section. The amendments made by this section apply to costs incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a new section is added for the exclusion of gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. The exclusion of gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation applies to a domestic C corporation organized for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90% of expenses related to this activity. The exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
